title.narrative: Down to Zero Indonesia

description.narrative: CSEC is a fundamental violation of children’s rights. It includes child prostitution, child pornography and child trafficking for sexual purposes. Many children lack the knowledge and capacity and/or the ability to speak out against or resist these forms of exploitation. Any objections they might have are ignored or not taken seriously by policy makers or the police, and often not even by their own parents. The communities in which these children live are not always safe for them. Their families are often unaware of the risks their children face, and in some cases they even encourage their children to enter child prostitution. Norms and values that tolerate violence against women are widespread and these are conspiring to make the victims feel ashamed. Furthermore, laws and policies are often not implemented or enforced, and this leads to large-scale impunity (the people who are guilty of this exploitation are going unpunished). In addition to all this, the private sector is not always aware of the effects it can have on CSEC and it could be underestimating its responsibility.

During the course of 2016, a learning agenda will be worked out and this will focus on the continuous assessment of the assumptions on which the project’s design and Theories of Change (ToC) have been based. The ToC will be critically reviewed every year at country, regional and alliance levels so that strategic adjustments can be made to ensure the maximum impact of the interventions.
Learning will also be an outcome of the programme’s evaluation agenda. A baseline will be conducted in the first half of 2016 and a mid-term review and final evaluation are scheduled for 2018 and 2020 respectively.

In the Netherlands the project will provide input for evidence-based lobbying of the Dutch government. It will also link with the Dutch tourism industry and a campaign called ‘Don’t Look Away’. There will also be opportunities for visibility through newspaper and magazine (Vice Versa) articles, radio interviews, presentations during forums and conferences.

Regional and country-specific plans will be developed and the relevant activities, based on the overall intervention strategies, will be designed during the inception phase (between January and June 2016).

SUMMARY The Down to Zero (DtZ) project in Indonesia is part of a broader initiative by an alliance comprising of Plan International Netherlands, Defence for Children – ECPAT Netherlands, Terre des Hommes Netherlands, ICCO and Free a Girl. It is combatting the commercial sexual exploitation of children (CSEC) through preventative and protective measures that focus on actual child victims and children who are at risk of commercial sexual exploitation. The project will empower young girls and boys, create safer communities, assist in law enforcement and policy implementation and work together with the private sector, such as the tourist industry.
In Indonesia, the project is being implemented by Plan International Indonesia, Terre des Hommes and ECPAT. It will run between January 2016 and December 2020 in Jakarta, Lombok and Surabaya, working with children, families, communities, the government and private-sector actors to prevent CSEC.

Sustainability will be further addressed during the design of the project in Indonesia.
The changes that will be introduced by the DtZ project in Indonesia will be sustainable. It will include various strategies, such as capacity development and policy influencing, both of which will increase sustainability. Institutional sustainability will be supported by the fact that the project focuses on strengthening the capacity of all local partner organisations. This will include carrying out assessments of individual organisational capacity and annual assessments of the progress being made in customised capacity-strengthening plans. The financial sustainability of the project’s outcomes and, more notably, the processes of change that it will start up, will depend on the financial and organisational sustainability of local partner organisations after the programme has finished. All these aspects will receive plenty of attention during the capacity-strengthening phases that will be developed and rolled out with all the local partner organisations.

The DtZ programme will address the consequences and root causes of CSEC, such as poverty, lack of education, gender imbalances and cultural norms and values that encourage such sexual exploitation.
It will do so in four interconnected ways. Firstly, it will empower children. By means of child-led (online) campaigns and life-skills and vocational trainings, children will be encouraged to speak up and protect themselves if they feel in danger of being exploited. It will also offer them possible alternative sources of income.
Secondly, by making them agents of change they will be strongly involved in mobilising parents, community and religious leaders, nurses and teachers to become allies in the struggle against CSEC. The active engagement of men and boys, including fathers, brothers and peers, as well as potential offenders, will be crucial in changing norms and values in communities. Furthermore, a well-functioning referral system connected to formal child-protection bodies will make communities safer for children.
Thirdly, laws and policies to combat impunity must be implemented and enforced. By showing governments the scale of the problem through research data and by supporting the development of practical local action plans, government officials will be more willing to address the problem, and with sufficient budget.
Lastly, the private sector will be encouraged to commit to zero-tolerance towards the sexual exploitation of children. The successful Code of Conduct for the Protection of Children from Sexual Exploitation in Travel and Tourism will be further promoted and it will serve as an example for other industries.

The DtZ project in Indonesia builds on the results obtained and the lessons learned from previous interventions carried out by Plan, Terre des Hommes and DCI-ECPAT. In Plan’s case the project will build on the success Plan has achieved with its community-based child-protection mechanism (CBCPM) approach.
Plan defines CBCPM as “a network or group of individuals at community level who work in a coordinated manner towards the protection of children from all forms of violence, in all settings. These mechanisms can be local or externally initiated and supported and either formal or informal in the way they are structured and work. CBCPMs are linked together and contribute to other child-protection systems.”
CBCPMs are designed to protect children from all forms of violence, abuse and exploitation, especially when it comes to CSEC. Mechanisms for community-based actions against CSEC prevent, monitor and refer all cases. They are also linked to existing child-protection systems at higher levels that are being managed by the responsible governmental actors.
Plan has been very successful in achieving official and effective linkages between CBCPMs and government-led child-protection systems.

The end beneficiaries include the actual victims and children at risk of being sexually exploited for commercial purposes in xxx districts of Jakarta, Lombok and Surabaya. The main focus will be on the most vulnerable children under the age of 18, while some elements will also include young people up to the age of 25. A specifically targeted group will be the exploited children, particularly girls, of ethnic communities.

The lobbying and advocacy part of the project and its thematic orientation on CSEC will provide plenty of opportunities for visibility in Indonesia. This will probably be through newspaper articles, radio and television interviews and programmes, presentations during conferences, and media and public campaigns.

title.narrative: # of girls trained to raise issues of CSEC among their peers

comment.narrative: # of girls trained to raise issues of CSEC among their peers

Girls especially have strong boundaries in such a rural area like Lombok, once the girls in one community join our regular meeting it keep spreading to another part area all around the villages so it easy to invite another girl, again after earthquake many girls join our activity at Child Friendly spaces. We held many activities to raise our CSEC issue in CFS area that why number of girls more increase that what it planned.

title.narrative: Targeted communities are safer, offer better protection to child victims and can prevent children from becoming (re)victimised.

description.narrative: Linkt aan 0213 Communities encourage children and youth to develop their potential and claim their rights (specify)

title.narrative: # of child protection committees supported

comment.narrative: # of child protection committees supported

Q4: Two of CBCPM in lombok, Rembitan and Wajageseng village was established. This was sending area for CSEC. Many children from this district migration to another area in Lombok or outside Lombok to work as song partner, waitress even its more vulnerable as children in this area living without parents as the parents is migrant worker outside Indonesia. We also encourage another CBCPM to share best practice to new commited CBCPM.

title.narrative: Market leaders or branch associations of at least three private sector industries are actively engaged in the protection of children against CSEC.

description.narrative: Linkt met Plan resultaat 0411 The private sector responds to the needs & rights for children and youth

title.narrative: # of companies sensitized on CSEC

comment.narrative: # of companies sensitized on CSEC

jointly for Gagas and Bandungwangi
For Plan International, this sensitization includes a strong gender equality component.

In Lombok: 12 companies engaging in our activity together in prevention together with the CBCPM. Prevention activity such as sharing session on how linked the refferal system/ reporting if private sector found CSEC case and how they can reporting it to authority with help from CBCPM.
In Jakarta: 3 companies have carried out the implementation of a child protection system and prevention of CSEC cases while continuing by conducting CSEC prevention (socialization) in internal company to all employees.

jointly for Gagas and Bandungwangi

This has been done in Jakarta, that newly reached private sector in North Jakarta including SPA, Massage, Billiards, and Internet cafes. Information about Child Rights and CSEC was delivered on this training.

title.narrative: Local government apply policies, plans of actions, budgets and protocols to effectively combat CSEC.

description.narrative: Linkt met Plan resultaat 0611 Policies and legislations are being aligned with the rights of children and youth and gender equality

title.narrative: # of government officials trained on CSEC

comment.narrative: # of government officials trained on CSEC

Government officials participated in the Workshop on Formulation of Standard Operational Procedure (SOP) in referral and reporting system. This workshop was help Jakarta and Lombok area to find the way and accurate in referral and reporting CSEC case. Government work closely with communities for reporting case and also strengthen communication between government especially service provider and CBCPM (LPAD/RPTRA).

comment.narrative: # of lobby and advocacy documents presented to government
Gagas and Bandungwangi

title.narrative: # of media campaigns on CSEC conducted

comment.narrative: # of media campaigns on CSEC conducted
Both partners

Media campaign conducted: 1. Referral and reporting system in village and sub-district level 2. Small enterprise business information about child rights (Sticker and Roll banner) 3. Children campaign tools

title.narrative: # of meetings held with Government officials

comment.narrative: # of meetings held with Government officials
Jointly for Gagas and Bandungwangi

In Lombok: 5 times audiency* and regular meeting conducted by involving DP2KBP3A, Tourism agency, health agency, Social welfare agency, social workers group, Integrated Service of Women Empowerment and Child Protection at West and Central Lombok districts with focus on refferal system in handling CSEC case.
In Jakarta: 2 times audiency with agency of Women Empowerment and Children Protection of Jakarta city was conducted by CBCPM/RPTRA, community representatives and Bandungwangi which aimed to bring facts on effective CBCPM model through RPTRA (Child friendly open public place) which has CSEC prevention. Discussion on SECTT situation with Tourism department with East Jakarta representative. This was aim to inform them what is SECTT and how government should have an action such as regulation or campaign for SECTT prevention.
